abstract: American boutique banks like Compass Advisers are gaining traction in China, using well-placed associates, serendipitous connections and specialized knowledge to strengthen their ties.
snippet: American boutique banks like Compass Advisers are gaining traction in China, using well-placed associates, serendipitous connections and specialized knowledge to strengthen their ties.
lead_paragraph: Last September in a restaurant on Israel’s Mediterranean coast, Ze’ev Goldberg, a partner at the boutique investment bank Compass Advisers, listened to Ren Jianxin, the chairman of China National Chemical, explain how he turned a paltry 10,000 renminbi loan (about $1,500) into a $24 billion company.

headline.main: When Competing With Big Banks, Smaller Can Be Better
